name: Suspected Iranian Counterintelligence Operation
description: TTPs identified in alleged Iranian counterintelligence operation

techniques.comment: The attacker used a network of over 35 fake recruiting websites containing extensive Farsi decoy content, including job offers and Israel-related lures. Upon entry, the targeted users were required to enter their personal details as well as their professional and academic experience, which were subsequently sent to the attackers.

The campaign used multiple fake domains to run its operations. Some of these include beparas[.]com, parasil[.]me, darakeh[.]me, and kandovani[.]org. This can be associated with the use of DGAs to create new domains for command and control servers.
The campaign used social media platforms to disseminate links to the fake recruitment websites.
The suspected counterintelligence operations collected data on Iranians and domestic threats who may be collaborating with intelligence and security agencies abroad, particularly in Israel.
The campaign used personal websites to lure its targets. It posed as a recruitment firm looking for employees and required targets to fill out a form with personal and professional details.
This involves the attackers' activities being blocked and disrupted, their accounts being terminated, and measures being put in place to protect users.
From as early as 2017 the suspected counterintelligence operations have been running campaigns that featured a network of fake recruitment websites.
The websites contained Telegram contact links, which were likely used for communication.
The websites contained forms that when filled out, sent information back to the attackers.
The domain beparas[.]com had publicly available WordPress user data. The username listed may have provided insights into the identity of the campaign operators.
